reviewText:
I played this on the Atari ST many many years ago. Seeing it is a fraction of what I paid for the game back when it came out in the 80s, I snapped it up.

Field battles
=========
The controls are very strange on the PC, and doesn't feel as fluid as when I played it on the Atari ST all those years ago. In fact the controls during the land battles is odd, as in this version you select your unit (cannon, calvary or infantry) and then select an enemy unit and then let it psuedo" auto attack.... you maintain full control over the movement of your last unit you clicked but you can not manually attack with it
date:
it has to auto attack the enemy unit you clicked on if it is in range.

Train Highjacking/Defence
==================
This seems to be changed slightly
recommended: instead of jumping onto the train and running along the top to get to the engine
hoursPlayed: you now stay on a horse
voteText:
riding along side the train shooting the defenders on the train and ducking under trees or jumping over rocks.

Fort Defence/Attack
=============
They changed this entirely
helpfulPercent: no longer is it the platform game where you ran along the walls of the fort beating the defenders
votesHelpful:
it's a shooting range where you have to shoot a number of targets to win. These targets will duck in and out of cover.

Overall
=====
For back in the day when computer power was limited this was a good game for its' day... however given the advancements in strategy and action games over the last three decades. The gameplay in this is very simple compared to what we have available in recent years. It would probably be something you give to a young child to play or introduce to strategy games rather than throw them in the deep end with something like civilization.

Although nice to be reminded of childhood games and be able to play them once again
votesTotal: this version leaves me just wanting to get an emulator and run that version instead.\n\nAnd yeah it left out all the goofy music too!"

reviewText:
A modern retouching of the game North & South.  The original came out around the time that I was born and I remember playing it often with my dad and uncles when I was very young.  Much of the gameplay is very similar, though a few aspects have been modified or added to the game.

The most obvious change is the graphic quality of the game.  As it was always a game based on humor, the new graphics work well and do not detract from the game in any way.

The economic system still works mostly the same as it used to, owning two separate train stations allows a train to go between them at the end of your turn to generate gold for your treasury.  However, now instead of acquiring a new unit after filling your safe, you have a store that you can purchase from.  This store includes new units (half the price that they were in the original), protection from Indian and Mexican attacks, protection from storms, and additional ammunition for your cannons in battle.

Combat seems to have been overhauled and simplified, however, which is my main complaint with the game.  No longer do you bounce between using direct control over your units trying to outmaneuver your opponent, now it's simply giving commands with the mouse as if it were an RTS.  This removes a significant amount of the skill that played a massive role in the original.  Taking a fort has changed as well.  Instead of, for lack of a better term, playing a 2D platformer beat-em-up to get from one side of the  fort to the other to raise your flag, you now sit in a single position hiding behind cover and popping up to shoot enemies until none of them are left.  These systems are not neccessarily bad, but may steal a little bit of the nostalgia from the old game if that's why you picked it up.

All in all, the game is a simple, board game like game that can be played locally against a friend. I recommend it as a fun, casual experience, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone looking for something hardcore.

reviewText:
My God.

What has been the greatest disappointment of my gaming life?

Was it the mismanaged, horribly optimized release of Assassin's Creed: Unity, a game which had the potential the bring one of history's most compelling settings to life in a 1-to-1 reproduction of Paris, but instead delivered an unplayable mess to PC?

Was it the desperate expectations of Half Life: Episode 3's release (any release!) after more than a decade since its mother title brought us to a new plateau of quality and entertainment?

No. It was a ♥♥♥♥-house port" of an NES game that I was totally obsessed with as a kid.

If you were a fan of North and South for the NES or the Amiga

reviewText:
This game in 5min - no commentary
https://youtu.be/OwZahsYTPkA

A cute little game.
This was on amigo, nes, and now tablets. this is based on the tablet version.
You play moving your little guys on the map in turns taking states when you land on them. you get a gold for each fort you own as long as 2 are connected by a railway.
Fighting takes place in a minigame with 3 kinds of troops fast cavalry, slow foot soldiers, and the cannons (limited ammo).
Some have destroyable bridges. you win by taking out all your opponents people or making them retreat.
You don't have full control mainly just click your unit and tell it who to attack or where to move. you can also set it to dice rolls instead of combat.
There are 2 other mini games when you take/defend a fort or try to rob/defend a train done by being in a state when a enemy train passes.
Forts are a click minigame where you click enemies when they come out of cover and you can duck to dodge shots.
Train heists are done by the robber ducks, jumps, and shoots at enemies on the train when they peak out or jump at them and the defender picks spots that his guys will jump/attack from.

reviewText:
Ich bin ein riesiger Fan vom alten Original North&South.....ich habe das Original gespielt ohne ende. Mit meinem besten Kumpel damals. Stunden voller Spass.
Dann dieses Remake. Voller Hoffnung und noch mehr Vorfreude.......und nach 10 Minuten die totale Enttäuschung.
Wie kann man einen Klassiker so zugrunderichten?
Die Steuerung ist eigentlich nur noch der blanke Horror. Auf der Strategiekarte kann man seine Armeen nicht bewegen solange man im Vollbildmodus ist. Das ist echt kein Scherz.  Man muss in den Fenstermodus wechseln um seine Armeen bewegen zu können. Traurig, einfach nur traurig. Aber kommt noch besser.
Der taktische Kampf......seufz....wie kann man nur....heul.
Hier mal ein kleiner Tatsachenbericht von einem Gefecht:
Kampf beginnt. Tastatursteuerung? Fehlanzeige. Alles mit der Maus. Also Einheiten anklicken, aufs Ziel klicken, rest machen sie automatisch.........Ja, sollten sie zumindest. Ich nehme meine Infaterie, klicke auf den Punkt wo sie hinsollen. Wähle dann meine Kavallerie und geb ihnen die feindlichen Kanonen als Ziel. Will wieder zu meiner Infanterie wechseln da sie gleich einem Angriff ausgesetzt sind durch die gegnerischen Infanterie. Also draufgeklickt und....nichts. Meine noch immer ausgewählte Kavallerie bewegt sich plötzlich in Richtung meiner Infanterie, die grad niedergemetzelt wird durch den Beschuss der feindlichen Infanterie. Meine zurückballern? Häh, wieso auch.....pazifismus yeah! Meine Kavallerie fällt dem Kanonendonner zum Opfer und meine Geschütze wurden eh gleich niedergeschossen. Alles in allem hat das Gefecht nicht mal ne Minute gedauert.

Vorbei die Zeiten wo man beim original Klassiker die Cursortasten nutzen durfte um seine Soldaten selber zu steuern nur um dann die Leertaste zu vergewaltigen. Achja, was waren das noch für herrliche Zeiten wo Spiele genauso funktionierten wie sie sollten.

Selbst für 50 Cent würd ich das Spiel nicht mehr weiterempfehlen. Behaltet lieber die Erinnerungen an das Original, als sich die Hoffnung auf ein gutes Remake mit diesem Mist zu versauen. Der Name eines guten Spieles wurde mit diesem DING regelrecht durch die ♥♥♥♥e gezocken. Schade

R.I.P.
North&South
Geboren: als die Zockerwelt noch in Ordnung war
Gestorben: 10.Mai 2012 als dieser Mist das Licht der Welt erblickte
War eine geile Zeit mit dir

reviewText:
Edit; after playing a couple of hours this left a bitter taste actually.
I've played the original back in '92, this one seems like a decent attempt to revive the oldie but the mini games are not balanced and fail to deliver the intended fun. The Train hijacking and the train defense mini game is alright, the battle mini game is a little bit too fast and lack actual conrtol over your troops, but the fort defense and fort capturing mini game is too fast to complete successfully [unless you use the “ESC” cheat, which is tapping Esc just before the enemy pop up behind cover and aiming while the game is paused ;) ]

You can grab it while on sale for a couple of bucks, just to have a few hours of casual fun and a few laughs. Nothing too serious though.

reviewText:
This is one of those classic games that most would be glad to see again. When you launch the game, you see the familiar title screen inspired by the original, and indeed, most of the game is heavily influenced by the original North vs South. The principle of the game is the same - you select either the Union or Confederates and play through a strategic map, where you buy units and send them to capture territories. Battles are real-time and involve switching between cavalry, infantry and artillery. Mini-games are used to capture and defend forts and rob trains – though the side-scrolling fort stage from the original has been replaced by a point-and-click Cabal-style shooting level. If you’ve played the original, these elements will all be familiar, but with updated cartoony graphics.

Unfortunately, the game is nowhere near as fun. Firstly, it’s blatantly obvious that this is a mobile port, and it’s a poor one. There is no keyboard control; everything is done with the mouse. And this is very clumsy. Battles are no longer the tactical decision making and charge-fire shots from the original, but point-and-click affairs. And while there is an element of strategy, it’s hampered by clumsy selection and unit switching. Units overlap, making it frustrating to give orders to the right unit, and making you really, really want to have at least one button on the keyboard that allows you to switch units.

The mobile platform is more evident in the shooting minigames. The action buttons are pleased on the left side of the screen – typical of a tablet layout – while the action takes place in the middle and right of the screen. The fort shooting level is terribly frustrating for those reasons. Enemies pop up behind cover in a whack-a-mole manner, but they’re spread so far apart that it’s agonising to use the mouse. To make things worse, sometimes two enemies pop up at once and shoot you, and it is impossible to hit both with the mouse. It’s easy with a touch-screen mobile, but forget doing it with the mouse. And since you need to capture forts to win the game, you may find that you’ve wiped out all the enemy armies and stopped their supply, but struggle to end the campaign due to the frustrating fort level.

Even so, the game is disastrously short. A “campaign” will typically last 3 turns. In short, this isn’t worth the $2.50 sale price.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Czx9kcIMwaM

reviewText:
North vs South,

You might remember it from the Amiga days and it was lots of fun.
This version is a sort of remake and does cover the basic aspect of the original. Some things are different though. The biggest one, which is also its major flaw, is the mouse control during the battles. In the original one you could move your units with the joystick and fire by pressing a button. Well, that's all gone now. Now it's just click where to go and to attack.
That, is a major flaw.
As it is, I would not recommend it, unless they fix the battle control to let's say WASD for movement and mouse button 1/space to fire. Besides of that, nothing wrong.
